posts.cooked:
Hello Everyone!

We have alot of things in development that I am sure will surprise and interest many of you but before releasing all of that I need to plan out the changes you would love to see in YAGSL . I know we had a few setbacks this year and we have discussed all of our options to make sure these issues never happen again! Here is our current plan for YAGSL to vastly improve everything from delivery to utilization next year!

Monorepo:

YAGSL will follow the lead of WPILib, PhotonVision, and many more projects by centralizing our repositories into 1 with GitHub actions controlling releases. (We used GitHub actions to make every new release this season!)

More examples!

The current system of having one GIANT example for the most complex robot is too difficult to navigate, or understand by most new teams so we are switching it up and creating several new examples based off the current one. We will have SwerveDrive with a drive forward autonomous SwerveDrive with drive forward autonomous and vision using PhotonVision for a global pose SwerveDrive with drive forward and vision using limelight for a global pose SwerveDrive using PathPlanner for autonomous SwerveDrive using Pathfinder for autonomous SwerveDrive Field-Oriented and a drive forward autonomous SwerveDrive field-oriented and PathPlanner autonomous SwerveDrive field-oriented and PathPlanner with PhotonVision for global pose SwerveDrive field-oriented and PathPlanner with Limelight for global pose

SwerveDrive with a drive forward autonomous

SwerveDrive with drive forward autonomous and vision using PhotonVision for a global pose

SwerveDrive with drive forward and vision using limelight for a global pose

SwerveDrive using PathPlanner for autonomous

SwerveDrive using Pathfinder for autonomous

SwerveDrive Field-Oriented and a drive forward autonomous

SwerveDrive field-oriented and PathPlanner autonomous

SwerveDrive field-oriented and PathPlanner with PhotonVision for global pose

SwerveDrive field-oriented and PathPlanner with Limelight for global pose

Updated documentation

The documentation this year felt out of date with the Shuffleboard update so we will fix that and move all documentation references from Shuffleboard to Elastic; which is my preferred method of setting up YAGSL anyways.

In-code configuration

In-code configurations have always been possible but have been very VERY ugly and while I do not like the idea of having a giant java constants file just for your SwerveDrive it should be done with relative ease.

Configuration classes.

Currently configuring a swerve drive is done through helper functions inside of SwerveDrive and SwerveModule which was acceptable until it became too large and unwieldy so its time to correct that mistake! I do not want to break existing code so I may have to find a creative way to add depreciation notices to those functions while providing the same functionality and replacing them with a controlling configuration class. I will probably make SwerveDrive and SwerveModule extend a class which modifies the controlling config class for this.

Web configurator update!

The existing web configurator was written to be as functional as possible as quickly as possible. It is not pretty; does not warn you when you might have done something wrong; and does not give you as many hints as it should. I aim to improve this to make it easier to use.

Dynamic vendordep importing

A test of this is already live, but WE HAVE HEARD AND LISTENED TO YOUR COMPLAINTS ABOUT TOO MANY VENDORDEPS! We are working on a way to dynamically load all vendordeps that way you only need to install what you use! Currently it is only working with ThriftyNova’s.

Better brushed motor support

Right now brushed motor support is basically undocumented because it has never been tested by me personally, however we will improve brushed motor support to allow for external encoders on azimuth/steering/angle motors that way teams don’t have to rely on any specific setup for brushed motor on modules and can swap it out as needed.

A configuration app!

This has been in development for a while and might not be released this season but we are actively trying to make this happen still!

I am still on the fence about a few things like allowing gear ratios for absolute encoders; aliases for common swerve module configurations; and more!

Please respond to this thread with any recommendations for improvements, suggestions!

posts.name: elijah lipscomb
posts.cooked: Images to go along with pid tuning would be sick. (Watching a 1 hour tutorial on it was painfull)

Images for PID tuning is difficult and I dont think gets the point across as well as browser tuner examples that the WPILib docs has; which could replace the video entirely if you wanted it to.

In this section, we will tune a simple position controller for a turret. The tuning principles explained here will also work for almost any position-control scenarios under no external loading. Tur...

Combined with the PID tuning table in the docs its a really quick way to get spun up on it. In my opinion at least.

link_counts.title: Tuning a Turret Position Controller — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
From a CSA perspective… there was a critical issue where the robot didn’t restart if was using REV devices and it crashed in a match while connected to the FMS . There was a fix available, but not published when I CSA ’ed at a Week 4 event. I only knew about it from watching the CSA Slack. By my next event, Week 6, the fix was showing as available in the vendor deps VS Code plugin, but still wouldn’t update (the old Manage Vendor Libraries worked.)

I saw this impact 3 teams Week 4, and 2 teams Week 6. It’s sad to see a team whose robot was dead on the field during a match.

TL;DR; Consider finding a way to get critical fixes published faster. Consider ways for CSA ’s to help teams update without an internet connection.

This is a tough problem. I am able to publish via the old way and have it available instantly but I currently do not have any automation to deploy a PR to GitHub - wpilibsuite/vendor-json-repo: WPILib Vendor JSON Repository which is what the vendordep plugin uses. Even if i did it would take some time (a few mins to a few hours) for one of the WPILib maintainers to merge it in.

I would have to differentiate between beta releases and full releases too.

I will try to get some more CD so i can automatically publish a PR to the vendordep-json-repo though. Thank you for pointing this out!

link_counts.title: GitHub - wpilibsuite/vendor-json-repo: WPILib Vendor JSON Repository

posts.name: Michael Hill
posts.cooked:
nstrike:

The current system of having one GIANT example for the most complex robot is too difficult to navigate, or understand by most new teams so we are switching it up and creating several new examples based off the current one.

I don’t know. I found the giant example as a PERFECT skeleton for our team’s code. This was 1.) My team’s first year with swerve, and 2.) My team’s first year with Java. Having the nearly complete code saved us a huge amount of time and work trying to figure out how to use the code. One of my complaints with some of the vendor libraries is that, yes, they do provide examples, but for a team that struggles with software, it was often difficult to know where to place that bit of code. So having everything in context was a huge learning opportunity. I don’t think we would have figured out how to incorporate vision pose updates with photonvision had it not been for the large example.

posts.name: Owen Flanagan
posts.cooked: It almost looks like that kind of example will still exist as one of the options. The change is that there will also be some simpler options. Correct me if I’m wrong.

posts.name: Michael Hill
posts.cooked:
nstrike:

SwerveDrive field-oriented and PathPlanner with PhotonVision for global pose

yeah, I guess you’re right: SwerveDrive field-oriented and PathPlanner with PhotonVision for global pose

posts.name: kieran
posts.cooked: I very much agree; it made it soooo much easier for our team to get started this year. I do think splitting it is the right move though. More examples is always better!

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
Our team was extremely impressed with YAGSL all across the board.

One thing we love is the deployed json configuration tooling, since it lets us run the same code on both our 4 module standard bot and a 2 module testbench bot, and from then on any new YAGSL project just gets a fully tuned drive right out of the gate. Wonderful setup and helps our newcomers easily get to driving

I think there was definitely two things we ran into though:

Unexpected and unclear documentation about the “right way” to handle switching fieldcentric driver input between red and blue side. This resulted in our team getting it working, but the resulting code was far messier than it needed to be.

Unexpected and unclear documentation about the “right way” to handle switching fieldcentric driver input between red and blue side. This resulted in our team getting it working, but the resulting code was far messier than it needed to be.

Mostly at random every few matches, our Navx2 running in SPI mode would disconnect the moment auto started, which was eventually traced so some YAGSL interaction forcing a a gyro reset. This cost us multiple autos (and a couple matches) before we could sort it out and use USB mode and resolve the issues. Documenting such quirks on the site (and preferably, the configuration tool) would help a lot for discoverability and avoidance of odd hardware combinations. We only found this buried in a chief delphi post after effectively pinning down the issue and specifically searching for it to confirm the fault.

Mostly at random every few matches, our Navx2 running in SPI mode would disconnect the moment auto started, which was eventually traced so some YAGSL interaction forcing a a gyro reset. This cost us multiple autos (and a couple matches) before we could sort it out and use USB mode and resolve the issues. Documenting such quirks on the site (and preferably, the configuration tool) would help a lot for discoverability and avoidance of odd hardware combinations. We only found this buried in a chief delphi post after effectively pinning down the issue and specifically searching for it to confirm the fault.

Document a routine to recover JSON configuration files from the remote deploy folder. While not common, sometimes we’d need to access those to tweak something, and it’s just enough unfamiliar unix work that it was throwing off our newer programmers. Without appropriate mentorship, I could see this being a problem for some teams.

Document a routine to recover JSON configuration files from the remote deploy folder. While not common, sometimes we’d need to access those to tweak something, and it’s just enough unfamiliar unix work that it was throwing off our newer programmers. Without appropriate mentorship, I could see this being a problem for some teams.

Better brushed motor support

Right now brushed motor support is basically undocumented because it has never been tested by me personally, however we will improve brushed motor support to allow for external encoders on azimuth/steering/angle motors that way teams don’t have to rely on any specific setup for brushed motor on modules and can swap it out as needed.

Having implemented a swerve with talons this year, this is the number one thing I’m excited for

posts.name: Sisters 1st
posts.cooked:
tekdemo:

Mostly at random every few matches, our Navx2 running in SPI mode would disconnect the moment auto started, which was eventually traced so some YAGSL interaction forcing a a gyro reset. This cost us multiple autos (and a couple matches) before we could sort it out and use USB mode and resolve the issues. Documenting such quirks on the site (and preferably, the configuration tool) would help a lot for discoverability and avoidance of odd hardware combinations. We only found this buried in a chief delphi post after effectively pinning down the issue and specifically searching for it to confirm the fault.

Us and FRC3142 saw the same things this year. Very frustrating until we switched to USB. Besides this, YAGSL was flawless this year.

You guys were definitely not the only ones frustrated about that. I try to catch things ahead of time and even had a team near me who uses a NavX this year and i was relying on them to let me know of anything like this during the beta (November-Jan) and nothing like this came up.

I will try my best to make sure this doesn’t happen again!

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: I talked to a team from outside the US that wanted to use YAGSL , but didn’t because it didn’t support metric units.

That was a concern but i dismissed that concern as teams could plug it into google with “what is Xmeters in inches” and copy then paste the calculation. Teams can now use Windows calculator for this too

posts.name: jwhite
posts.cooked:
I interacted only peripherally with YAGSL , as a CSA helping teams work with it.  First, it seems to be an incredible tool that allowed teams to get going quickly; so mad props are in order. What I’ve been telling my fellow mentors, though, is that it feels like it’s development speed has created some rough edges. The example of the critical update which you had to manually apply is a good example.  But another was when I was working with a YAGSL expert to help a team, and he was concerned that they had used an ‘old’ template to generate their code and that meant they were missing features.

The constructive advice I would offer is to increase the priority of stability.  That is, it’s more valuable to be reliable and predictable than to have the more features.  Or to have some very clear versioning; so when I go the web site, it says:  “Make sure you only use YAGSL 17.9 Blue compatible templates.”  Or make sure that when you google ‘ YAGSL example code’ the results don’t horrify you.

posts.name: Johnny Dreher
posts.cooked: We are experiencing odometry issues: over distances greater than 1 meter (approximately 4 feet—we’re from Brazil and use the metric system), the odometry begins to lose accuracy, with errors approaching almost 5%. I’m not sure if that’s an acceptable figure, but for high-precision challenges we need better. Is there a more advanced tutorial on how to calibrate it more effectively? We love YAGSL and even tried migrating to our own solution, but we’ve since abandoned that idea.

I have seen that issue before! Normally when odometry starts getting off like that its bc

wheels are worn so the diameter isn’t exactly what you calculated it at initially

diameter didn’t include the tread

gears are not greased

Gears inputted are incorrect

Chose to calculate your own ratio instead of using composition or while using composition and did not do it entirely correct

Hardware is subpar (like if odom has gyro drift bc you’re using an ADIS or NavX it’s fixable but not obvious)

Poorly tuned PIDs.

We will work on a more advanced tutorial but that is handled by my students instead of me.

posts.name: Johnny Dreher
posts.cooked:
We will try all this. Somethings, like real diameters and greased gears we already do it

Thanks a lot again

posts.name: Johnny Dreher
posts.cooked: We have implemented all this, and now we are a lot more acurated. We get 1,5% of error on 6 meters(about 20 feet). At 3meters we get under a 1%.
